t: How*pn beautiful you are, my darling! Oh,*ld how beautiful! Your*ld eyes behind your veil are doves. Your*ln hair is like a flock of goats descending*ld from the hills of Gilead.
Your*ln teeth are like a flock of sheep just shorn, coming*ld up from the washing. Each*ln has its twin; not*ld one of them is alone.
Your*ln lips are like a scarlet ribbon; your*ld mouth is lovely. Your*ln temples behind your veil are*ld like the halves of a pomegranate.
Your*ln neck is like the tower of David, built*ld with courses of stone; on*ln it hang a thousand shields, all*ld of them shields of warriors.
Your*ln breasts are like two fawns, like*ld twin fawns of a gazelle that*ld browse among the lilies.
Until*ln the day breaks and*ld the shadows flee, I*ln will go to the mountain of myrrh and*ld to the hill of incense.
You*ln are altogether beautiful, my darling; there*ld is no flaw in you.

Come*pn with me from Lebanon, my bride, come*ld with me from Lebanon. Descend*ln from the crest of Amana, from*ld the top of Senir, the summit of Hermon, from*ln the lionsâ€™ dens and*ld the mountain haunts of leopards.
You*ln have stolen my heart, my sister, my bride; you*ld have stolen my heart with*ln one glance of your eyes, with*ld one jewel of your necklace.
How*ln delightful is your love, my sister, my bride! How*ld much more pleasing is your love than wine, and*ln the fragrance of your perfume more*ld than any spice!
Your*ln lips drop sweetness as the honeycomb, my bride; milk*ld and honey are under your tongue. The*ln fragrance of your garments is*ld like the fragrance of Lebanon.
You*ln are a garden locked up, my sister, my bride; you*ld are a spring enclosed, a sealed fountain.
Your*ln plants are an orchard of pomegranates with*ld choice fruits, with*ld henna and nard,
nard*ld and saffron, calamus*ld and cinnamon, with*ld every kind of incense tree, with*ld myrrh and aloes and*ld all the finest spices.
You*ln are a garden fountain, a*ld well of flowing water streaming*ld down from Lebanon.
Awake,*pn north wind, and*ld come, south wind! Blow*ln on my garden, that*ld its fragrance may spread everywhere. Let*ln my beloved come into his garden and*ld taste its choice fruits.
